Bottom Line - this place is hit or miss.  If you work in the Fidi you can take some time to find the "hits" and its not a bad spot for Mexican.
author: Nic T.

description:
Oi chihuahua. I single-fingeredly? am writing this review as I slowly drift into what I fondly refer to as "flavor coma". Other less refined patrons may refer to this as a food coma. But I say NAY, this is more...much much more.

This morning as my co-worker and I went for "walkies" around the financial district we came across this tiny, hole in the wall, never heard of, I guarantee they re-use the chips type mexican restaurant. And let me tell you my friend, the smell alone brought my appetite to life. Thus, we made the calculated decision to leave for lunch a bit early to beat the rush of other, like-minded patrons but unfortunately our plans were foiled by that oh so evil...job. I can't believe my "job" actually expects me to "work" when I'm here. Preposterous! 

But I digress. As we came upon this establishment (finally) we found a long line out the door, but chose to wait it out. The line moved rather quickly, as people went in, ate and left without delay. Mainly no one delays after finishing their meal due to the dozens of pairs of eyes burning into the back of their heads with resentment for making others wait longer.

Once we were seated we were immediately served salsa, chips, and agua. (that's water for all you ignoramusses....usssss haha) The salsa was sooo good and the gravy boat it comes served in is an added bonus to the decor. Salsa was spicy enough to make a girl cry. And the best part? They refill your chips and salsa like THAT. *hopelessly tries to snap and fails*

We both ordered the tostada salads, his with beef, mine with chicken. The food arrived fairly quickly and there was so much of it. The chicken couldv'e been more flavorful but the dish was definitely worth the price. For $8 I was soo stuffed that I had to get a to-go box, and so did my co-worker (and he usually eats twice as much as me). 

The service was excellent, the waiters are all running around at lightning speed replenishing chips and salsa. My one and only con: the chips are stale and I think re-used. It looked as if they simply picked up the bowl of chips when a table was done, put it in the pile with all the other chip bowls, and gave you a different bowl--therefore creating the illusion of "new" and "fresh"
author: Scooby D.

description:
I'm not sure what has happened to this place, but it's going down hill. The waiters who work in the main dining area are great. Always friendly. The (2) girls at the counter are rude, unfriendly and could not be bothered with guests. They normally roll their eyes before actually answering your questions. Oh and BTW I speak Spanish and can understand what you are saying. 

I just ordered (takeout) an order of Nachos, grilled chicken, beans (no salsa) for $9.58. Let's see I was given a total of (16) chips..yes I counted as I was shocked when I opened the box as I sat down at my desk to eat. That equals to $0.59 per chip. I wonder how much it would of cost if the food was actually hot. 

I have an actual photo of the nachos should anyone want to see it. 

You get better service, portions, freshness at Chipotle or the tack truck on Battery & Pacific.
author: Paul R.

description:
in the financial district you can not get cheap mexican places to eat - love it  -
choice - basic carne asada - no beans
and my mexican coca cola
author: Fela K.

description:
This was one of my and my co-workers favorite spots to eat in SF. Probably ate here over 20 times. As soon as you sit down, there's a bowl of tortilla chips and one of the best salsas ever waiting for you. The guacamole is also very good. Mix the salsa and guacamole and you get heaven. I usually ordered the flautas combo with yellow and black beans. More than enough food. If you can finish all that plus the chips, you are a beast. 

Although I've since moved to NY, I regularly wish I could eat here just one more time.
author: Paul B.

description:
I really think I'd rate this one maybe 2.5 or even 2.75 stars. 

I ate here today for lunch with my gf. Now I've dined here for lunch on several occasions and I still come back occasionally. Why do I come back? 
-Salsa 
-Service 
Why would I maybe not come back? 
-Long wait (which is good because it should show they have a loyal following of customers; just bad for those impatient people) 
-Burrito supremo was just aiite (I've had better fo sho) 

Today I ordered combo#1 and i was much more satisfied with that then the burrito. 

So there's really no cons about this place, its just so-so to me but the lines here during lunch time is KrAAAzAy....
author: Julie F.

description:
My sophomore year in college, I wanted to lose weight, so my roomie told me that I should go on a diet of white rice and refried beans.  
Combined, she said, they form a legume (wtf?), CANCEL each other out, and you'll lose weight.  Our goal was to find all of the Mexican food places in San Luis Obispo and get rice & beans.  Before we'd leave, she would suggest that I get some to take home and put in the fridge for later.

That was one, big, starchy, FAT lie.  She probably lied to get me back for vomiting in the potted plants she kept out front - on multiple occasions.  Whoops.

It took me a month to realize that her diet plan was making me puff up like a sponge in water.  

Since then, I've steered clear of diet advice from people who hate you AND rice & beans.

Orale Orale, you make me want to forget that vindictive biyatch and then roll around in a bathtub of "legumes."  Which is nasty to write, but oh-so satisfying to read.
author: Janney B.

description:
No long lines after the hour of 1

Order away cuz there's barely anyone!

One enchilada does it for me!

But Luis will have two or even three!

He politely asks, please add some extra cheese,

And while your at it throw in some grease,

With an extra helping of sour cream, of course!

Eats every last bite without remorse :o)
author: Aim E.

description:
Viva Double Oral!

chips and salsa brought to the table as you are welcomed - 
promising kitchen smells for an anxious appetite,
beers and chips and smiles and salsa.
a blanket of all those other conversations encircle your table for privacy,
silverware against plates - a battle of the super huge burrito..
crunchy tacos and dripping sauces..  a long line is forming outside,
the food comes quickly - you can feel a little bit of pressure,
Order another beer from the whistling waiter,
Next time, we'll come earlier or later and we won't worry about time.

.................
author: Kenny R.

description:
You ever been so hungover that you go into your boss' office, crawl under the credenza and go to sleep?  

I came back from a meeting and couldn't find my trusty assistant.   Eh, she's at lunch I guess so I went into my office to start working and as I was working I could hear this weird sound that sounded like a cross between heavy breathing and a snore.  I looked around.  Thought I was trippin' and went back to work.  Still, there was that sound again.  Hmm. . .I zeroed in on it's location and lo and behold, there she was, sacked out like George Costanza in that famous episode from Seinfeld (although my girl was the O.G.) .  . . I fished her out from under the credenza and as she brushed off the dust bunnies she proceeded to explain why a nap was so desperately needed. . . I knew just the cure . . . a carne asada burrito from Orale Orale. . .we took a walk, got some food and she was right as rain and out from under my desk for the rest of the day!  

Orale Orale has cured many a hangover. . whether it be a wee bit of the hair o' the dog from an icy Margarita or a nice, fat, slightly greasy but in a good way carne asada burrito to soak up that queasy feeling . . Orale Orale is there for you.  Plus, their salsa is insanely good.  

So next time you're feeling a bit peckish after a night on the town, skip crawling under a desk and head to Orale Orale to cure what ails you.
author: Lainie L.

description:
I dig this place!  Simple good mexican food!  Long lines for lunch, so get there before noon. Burritos. Good.  Enchiladas, good.  Quesadillas, good. Chimichangas, mmmmmm great!  Refried beans done just right.  

service is pretty quick...considering they're so packed all the time!
author: Peter M.

description:
I suddenly dont feel very well. The reason very well maybe that I had  a giant bucket of salsa for lunch. Usually, I make it a point to go somewhere at least 2 blocks from my office, but today was the fuck that walk day. Since mexican was my fate today, and Orale Orale is right next door, I jumped from my window.

Into the bucket of salsa, that is. The line was long, the waiters kept us busy with tortillas and salsa. The tortillas were still there, and the salsa was gone in 2 minutes. After making a few rounds of salsa, the tortillas were peeking from the bottom of the plastic mug. Did I mention the burrito was on its way? Anyhoo, after 4 rounds of red hot salsa treatment, I decided to give the burrito a boot and crawled back to my office. 

And now I cant type anymore.
author: Sav B.

description:
Decent Mexican food.

Not great, but not bad either.  

Will return.

And if I hear someone else call it ORLE, ORLE.....
author: Daniela L.

description:
For over a decade, I've been going to Orale Orale for excellent chimichangas, fantastic margaritas and some of the best salsa in town. I wouldn't ever give away the secret of the margarita-to-go, but since the cat is out of the bag already, I'll just go ahead and sing its praises. Many times, my team would head out to Orale for lunch and spend a quiet afternoon at our desks sipping on our innocuous soda cups filled with the magical lime and tequila elixir. Sure, we could have been busted, but then the management would have to stop doing take out margaritas as well. 

For years, Orale Orale was the great equalizer - from management down to us lowly grunts, we would sit side by side with salsa laden chips in one hand and margaritas in the other. 

It's an Embarcadero Center legend and worth a visit for lunch or a very early dinner.
author: Avery G.

description:
You know that scene in Anchorman where Ron Burgandy is driving his sweet 1970 Pontiac over the bridge and he chucks his leftovers at an unsuspecting motorcyclist (a phenomenal cameo by Jack Black)? Remember what he says as he's throwing it?

"This burrito is good, but it IS filling!"
author: Anna K.

description:
Do I get something special for the 100th review??  A free meal maybe??  Hello??

I went here with a small group before heading out to the Comedy Club.  It's a place that's kind of hidden in the Financial District, in the shadow of the Hyatt Regency.  It just might be the only descent Mexican food place in the FiDi.  That includes *gasp* Chevy's.
I must admit I am spoiled by having good burritos just a short walk from my front door.  There is some good Mexican food in the Excelsior!

I loved the salsa.  It was fresh, with a little kick.  I should have had more chips!  But I was shy ... this time.  I had the enchilada plate with one beef, and one cheese.  I must say they are some of the best, outside of my own kitchen.  The plates come out super hot, (as the norm for Mexican food restaurants), with the standard rice and beans.

Lots of other plates and burritos are available.  I SO wish I worked downtown.  But instead I work in a hell hole boonie, with only Jack in the Crack, and an OK Dim Sum Place.  Soon, Orale .... soon.  This will be my twice weekly place!  I fully intend to try just about everything on the menu, except the fish.

Watch your glass, Tim.
author: Michael M.

description:
I used to go here every once in a while, and I was rarely happy after a meal. This is one of those places where you want the food to be better than it actually is. Now when I get a craving for Mexican food, I just wait to come home and go to Papalote.

There are open relatively late for a place in the Financial District, which has helped me on occasion. I stopped going here when Pancho Villa opened a spot on the Embacadero, but when that place left me disappointed, I just abandoned Mexican food downtown. There are long waits during the lunch hour, so not everyone has been able to leave them behind like I did.

In fairness, the portions are large, and the prices, while high compared to the Mission, are reasonable for the FiDi.
author: Timothy O.

description:
If you love authentic Mexican food (not the Tex-Mex Chevy's style of cooking), you'll really love Orale. This family-owned restaurant serves the very best chili rellenos around, along with flautas, enchiladas, chimichangas, quesadillas, and more. 

People line up around the block on Fridays for their to-die-for Crab Enchiladas. The house-made salsa has won blue ribbon awards at the California State Fair as the state's very best salsa for many years in a row, and no wonder -- it is a perfect combination of fresh, spicy, highly addictive ingredients. 

You can order items ala carte or as combinations/dinner with the traditional (and tasty) rice and beans.  My favorite dish is combination #5 -- a corn tortilla flauta stuffed with chili verde pork, and a perfect chili relleno.  I don't suggest the fish tacos -- they are not what this place is known for.  (If you're hot for F.T., try Rubens -- this San Diego hit is invading the Bay Area, and their fish tacos are sublime.)

Prices are what you'd expect in the financial district -- slightly more than in the Mission but not bad. (Without beverages, average full meal entree is under $10).

Pros: Friendly, Fresh, Muy Delicioso!

Special Pro:  They stock the Hecho en Mexico Coca Cola -- this is made with pure cane sugar, not the US corn syrup, and is the perfect accompaniment to a great Mexican lunch.  Try it -- you'll see the difference -- 100% better than the US-made Coke. 

Cons: can be crowded, a wait for table service is sometimes necessary -- go in off-hours (they are open until 8 p.m. -- perfect for those late nights in the office.)  Or, order take-out.
author: Bevy M.

description:
I think I have been spoiled by some certain south bay burrito places, so I can't say this was the "best" burrito I ever had, but it was definatley up there.

I had the steak burrito supremo, good stuff but next time I would skip on the extras, to much guac and sour cream at the bottom of the burrito.

On the upside this place is HELLA fast, even with a line out the door I was only there for like 10 minutes. A quick fix for a lunch hour that we all know is more like 15 minutes these days!
author: Alicia K.

description:
One word describes the people who could give this place more than 3 stars: amateurs. Let's put this place in context; the financial district is full of mediocre eateries and those you like aren't because they're good as much as everything else sucks and is overpriced. Having said that, Orale Orale is one of the better burritos you can get in the Financial District. 

Their burritos have lettuce (why?!), fairly tasty meat (I had carne asada---somebody here embarrassed themselves by saying they like the carnitas; there are no carnitas!), and are on the larger size as far as burritos go. To tell you the truth, I was expecting the worse and it didn't happen. It was fairly tasty and enjoyable but it cost me almost $8 with no drink and no chips.

If you're searching for a good burrito in the city, head to the Mission. If you absolutely, positively must eat a burrito during your lunch break and don't mind paying $7.00 for it, hit up Orale Orale . . . I guess.
author: Mario T.

description:
When I don't feel like walking around the Embarcadero for food, I come here for the grilled chicken burrito. Very reasonably priced at around 5 bucks. It's pretty good. But you can't get the guac or the sour cream, then it becomes way more expensive! it's not the best burrito I've tasted, but not the worst. I am usually in a hurry which is why I never sat in the restaurant area. Maybe I should try something different but the burrito is just easy to pick up and go. 

Service is fast and somewhat friendly and there is always mass loads of people out front so I must be missing something.
author: Lauren W.

description:
Since I went to school in Arizona, which isn't far from Mexico, I know what good Mexican food is. There aren't that many places in San Francisco which can live up to my definition of "good Mexican food," but this place can. If you want to take out food, make sure to call ahead and place an order or else you'll be stuck waiting for a while. If you are just going to sit down and enjoy a meal at a table, look for a worker and ask for a table. From my understanding you can bypass the intial line you see which you might think you need to order first, then sit down. But no worries, there are waiters/waitresses that will take your order. The salsa they provide on the table is SUPER spicy (in my opinion) so if you want non-spicy salsa, ask for it and don't be alarmed if a waiter jokes with you and says, "You mean white people salsa?" They're not being racist, or maybe they are...
 
I heard their breakfast is good too but I haven't ventured off to try it yet...maybe tomorrow morning.
author: Heidi C.

description:
I'm new to the Financial District (just moved in from Union Square) and I didn't know such a great Mexican restaurant existed in the area. I used to go to the Mission all the time during my lunch break since I was right beside BART, but now that I can't do that anymore, Orale Orale makes a great substitute. Despite the hustle and bustle during lunchtime, the service was good and very fast. My one concern is the food coma I got after eating there, and I know there are plenty more to come.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Go to Los Socios.

I just had a bad burrito experience (grilled chicken).  The grilled chicken was NOT fresh, and in fact, was stinky, and no not in an appropriate chicken fragrance sort of way.  The rice and pinto beans tasted as if they came from a box and can, respectively.  In fact, my tummy is grumbling fiercely, "Ayudeme!  Ayudeme!"

WSA (Weighted Star Average):  **.  Previous burrito experiences have been awesome.  I'm just uncomfortable and mad right now.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Pretty good burrito for the FiDi! I got the grilled chicken burrito, which was good...seems like a burrito you can count on, but I would not say it was the best burrito I've had. 

I really liked their rice though. It tasted like they put curry in it possibly, which I would never think of doing in a Mexican burrito, but it worked. Something a little different, but good!
author: Ken V.

description: I don't get why this place is popular. Let's see... average cheese-laden food, mashed refried beans instead of tasty pinto, and not enough tables at lunch... Yeah, that totally translates to good to me.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Best Salsa!  I grab food from here because  I want to eat their chips and salsa.  It's amazing!  The food is good and the prices are resonable.  But I really just like the salsa.  ;o)
author: R C.

description:
Stick with the enchiladas combo.  One ground beef, one chicken.  Hearty meal that really sticks to the ribs.  Rice might not be totally authentic, but maybe that's because it's really flavorful.  If there's one gripe, it might be that the chips are sometimes stale and there's only two versions of the salsa:  volcano hot and mild.  

If you go for lunch, beat the crowd and get there at 11:30.  Other than that, you're in for a long wait
author: Terence F.

description:
This is a prime lunch destination in the Financial District because the Mexican food is really good.  To start, the chips and salsa are tasty.  Be sure to order a large guacamole; it's the best I've ever had.  My favorite dish to order is the Dos Flautas plate, which comes with rice and beans.  I order them soft with carne asada.  Don't eat too much, or you'll have a pretty good food coma and struggle to stay awake in the afternoon!

It gets pretty packed by quarter of noon, so come early or end up waiting in line for a good 15-20 minutes at least.
author: Peter C.

description:
I give this place 4 stars because it is actually nice to dine in here during lunch hours.I usually get take out,but just sitting in here and enjoying a decent "orale,orale" lunch is nice.Other people who work like you and me need a break..and you can tell people are just relaxing with co-workers and enoying a meal or drink.

Crowded,yet really a decent place in FiDi to have lunch.The menu selection is good.Many options for people.especially the picky one's.

I had a baby burrito plenty of times and they are decent.I also had nacho's..decent too.

You may get confused because of the 2 lines.One for tables and one for just ordering to go.



-------


4/27 Orale also serves decent breakfast burritos and other stuff.If you don't come for lunch,well come for breakfast.

It beats the lunch rush..
author: Dani D.

description: I am a bit picky when it comes to the burrito, but this place fits the bill in the FiDi for lunch.  I love the salsa because it is spicy and I don't find yucky pieces of tomato in it (You know what I am talking about.  I HATE it when salsa has pieces of tomato core in it). The burrito itself is mediocre, but it passes the "I'll come back" test.   I always get the carne asada burrito and it comes with good quality meat.
author: Katharine A.

description:
What can I say about Orale Orale? It used to be on my weekly rotation for restaurants. It was dropped not because the food was anything but fantastic, but rather because my lunch group grew past four people and the tables there only seat four.

The salsa is quite good. The chips are average. The burritos are fantastic. The carne asada burrito specifically has good quality meat and is a good size. They have breakfast food if you get in early enough too.

I recently switched to a vegetarian lifestyle (I know, I'm nuts) and had their vegetarian burrito the other day and it was very good.

The service once you get seated (which may take a while at lunch with the line out the door) is very good. I don't believe they've ever forgotten anything I've asked for or brought me the wrong food.

Oh, and do try the Enchiladas with Nun Sauce. I'm not exactly sure what the real name is, but the sauce recipe comes from some group of nuns and it is very good and not like any enchilada sauce I've ever had before.

They have take-out as well. The line is super long for that too, but you can call ahead and they have a very quick turn around.

All in all, one of my favorite mexican restaurants in the city.
author: Jordan M.

description:
Almost every Friday I designate it Burrito Day!  I'm pretty much strapped to my cubicle everyday trying to race deadlines, and almost everyday I don't eat until 2pm.  So I look forward to that end of the week where I catch up on lost calories... I look forward to Burrito Days.

I've shopped around the FiDi, North Beach, and I'll peek around Chinatown at times (Mushu pork is close, but the Chinese just aren't fond of guac) for that perfectly wrapped meat, rice, and fat.    But Orale Orale has been constant and a big favorite of mine.  There are 2 lines (table service and takeout) in here everyday and both are often out the door.  Don't bother looking at their extensive menu of yummy lardy goodness.  Just go for a burrito.  Celebrate Burrito Day with me.  Yours can even fall on a Monday if you like.  

What is the exception here?  Say it with me -- "But-ta rice."  Ok, it really isn't rice with butter, but it has a lovely yellow hue to it and it's super moist.  I am guessing it was made with saffron.  The meats are juicy and they aren't sitting under a heatlamp where the marinade is drying out.  I do have to warn you that the pork can be rather chunky so grab a fork and dig in when need be.  But you'll find a nice suprise in the end, because all the meat juice, sauces, and spices have now pooled in at the bottom.  Those last 3 bites are heavenly... and a little messy.  Do like a hamster and suck on the bottom.  No wasting, k?

And one element they've mastered is the wrapping.  I've had some really gnarly "burrito knots" where the tortilla has been wrapped over so many times that it creates a big bundle that kills the the entire burrito texture.  I want to sink my teeth where it closes in, not stop midway in order gnaw at that damned knot.  So keep it loose!

Have a happy Burrito Day!
author: Chris T.

description:
Ive tried so many times to like them...Ive tried so many dishes...but it just doesnt cut it. The only thing I actually sorta enjoyed was their Burrito Supremo. Everything else is so bland. The only thing with falvor is the salsa.
I dont get why this place is always packed. I guess this is a Hit or Miss sorta place. Complete Miss for me.
author: Judith F.

description:
I'm thinking that Orale! means "got you, sucka!!!!" because what a freaking rip-off this place is.

I thought of trying this place about a year ago but read the yelps from back then and they weren't encouraging.  

A co-worker and I stood outside in the queue for 15 minutes in the god-damn cold, wind and threatening rain to have lunch here.  It was the co-workers choice.  

We thought of going next door to the Foccacia Bistro or whatever it's called, but neither one of us was liking the prospect of a sandwich or any of the other items on their board.

So, we gets back in line and shuffles in until a table becomes vacant.

I order one chicken taco with rice and beans.  Cha-ching!  Bank $7 to the owners who serve me up a chicken taco with no chicken!  I'm exaggerating.  It was a chicken taco with a sliver of chicken about the size of my thumb.  No joke...the size of my thumb!  

I dug around hoping to find more protein.  Alas, none was to be found, just the massive mound of lettuce they piled on top of two flour tortillas.

The salsa was not especially profound or extraordinary, the chips were greasy and waitstaff, well, I can't even remember what he/she looked like.  

They're like falcons swooping in for the kill.  Oh, so graceful, all you notice is that after waiting so long in the freaking cold that you're happy to know you're going to be fed and they are your ticket to food.  But, they are so cruel to plop down a $7 plate with one taco with a sliver of protein and barely one-quarter cup each of rice and beans.

This is not the place for me.
author: Maggie K.

description:
Love this place!  Whenever I decide to visit, I take an early lunch.  This place gets busy really quickly.

I usually get the enchilada combo.  Really good sauce.  The chips and salsa are really tasty too.  The staff is really helpful and quick to take your order.

I have also ordered the beef burrito to go before and that was really good as well.
author: C G.

description: I had the breakfast burrito ($5), you get what you pay for.  The burrito was super cheap and big, 2 stars, I'm pretty easy to please.  It was also produced for me very quickly, another star.  It did not taste good, no more stars.  If you're in a hurry before work or need something to fill your belly after a late night out, this place is exceptional, if you want good food, head somewhere else.
author: Spenser T.

description: After working near Orale Orale for almost 8 years, I thought it was time to try it. Every time I had passed there it was always packed. Jam packed. So much so that people would spill out into the street. And I'm not standing in traffic for lunch.  Well, now I can see why. The food is just amazing. Best chicken enchilada I have ever had. And my chille relleno was simply light and delightful. I could tell that the pepper was fresh. I highly recommend. But come early or late.
author: Valerie V.

description: This is the kind of place that puts grated Parmesan on nachos and charges $7 for a mix-and-Sauza margarita. But I guess that's what you get for trying to eat Mexican in the FiDi. Bonus star for decent service.
author: Colin M.

description: This place is solid- had an horchata and the best tacos al pastor I've ever had. Very friendly staff- carne asada burrito is just ok IMO- I'll be back for sure
author: M L.

description: Ordered Seafood Supremo Bowl for only $7.75. Delicious! The salsa is some of the best I've ever had.
author: Tony P.

description: Awesome Mexican food in the FiDi. The food is always spot on, and service is friendly and fast. Yes, it can seem like utter chaos at lunch time. What do you expect at noon in the FiDi? It's really no less insanity than Breaking Bread or even Soup Kitchen. The takeout line is your best bet, trust me. Order at the counter, hang out and get your food and get the hell out of there. If you have a lunch date, then try to show up before 12 or after 1:30. You'll have to stand in line to be seated, and then they will take your order. Don't complain, there's a method to the madness, and don't try to subvert the system (this is not freaking Occupy) by ordering in the takeout line, then try to steal a table away from the folks who have been waiting in line. As far as suggestions, we've tried everything from veggie options, carnitas, steak, seafood, burritos and tacos, and everything is really good. I'd give this place an extra half star if I could just on location alone. It's impossible to find something this yummy in the area, and as fast as they are in the take out line, I am sold for life.
author: Zehra A.

description:
Here's the context:  Location in the Financial District so not a lot of great taquerias like the Mission.  People get off work, fight over the elliptical machines and go to the various Starbucks multiple times a day.  Salads and sandwiches w/out mayo are hot.  

So what about the people who don't give a crap about their bodies and diets?  Who love Mexican food and yearn for a fix at least once a week?  GO HERE.  It's not the greatest in all of SF, but for the neighborhood it most certainly is.  Chimichangas are excellent, burritos are a bit flat but still tasty and their salsa is spicy, just how I like it.
author: Denise C.

description:
OMG. So I came here for dinner last week, and first off, the service was...lacking. The cashier lady was very brusque and did not make me feel welcome at all to be eating here. I ordered the quesadilla and the taquitos, and they both were...not well made. I had the quesdilla first, and it was just a soggy melty mess. I don't understand. I couldn't even pick up the quesadilla because the tortilla was still soft and all the cheese and chicken would ooze out. I had to eat it with a FORK. what kind of quesadilla has to be eaten with a fork?? Tastewise it was okay, but it was also so greasy and fatty that after two slices I couldn't eat any more and just threw the rest of it out. After that I saved the taquitos for lunch the next day. It was a little better, because after being in the fridge overnight, the taquito tortilla shells had harded enough that i could actually eat it without it falling apart on me. I always thought taquitos were like.. long thing cylinders though. These were more like fatty short rolls. The gross part was that there was a ton of sour cream in my box, and overnight it had become...a solid block. Does sour cream normally do this?? While I was eating, my food thawed out (I don't reheat my leftovers...haha) and then the taquito got oozy and fall-aparty again, but the sour cream was still solid.

I'm sad caus this place is so close to where I work, but it was really not worth it. AND OVERPRICED.
author: Melody L.

description:
I've only eaten here once. We took some volunteers out for a "thank-you" lunch. The food was good and cheap, but the service was not so good. As soon as we paid the bill they booted us out of our seats. Granted, the lunchtime line was out the door, but still. 

"Muy malo", as my people would say.
author: Lupe P.

description: Salsa makes or breaks any Mexican restaurant for me and theirs is great! It's always crowded, but worth the wait in my opinion. I love their chicken nachos and fish tacos.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
By 11:30 there is a line out the door...  so if you want to dine in for lunch, then you gotta get here by 11 or after 2...

I really like the vegetarian nachos and how each chip is still crunchy despite being loaded up with goodies.  But you gotta eat it there or else it's mush mush AND you can supplement with the the chips & salsa...  Rice and beans are also tasty - not the best, but still good.

I'm still waiting for the day that I remember that this place is open for breakfast to get me a breakfast burrito w/ chorizo.  That's got to be yum...
author: Christine T.

description:
I love getting take out burritos here and going to eat in the sun. You have to buy chips separately, which is odd. But they are cheap and plentiful. Small bag for 1-2 people, large bag for more. 

I love the unlimited chips and salsa when you sit down. The wait can be a bit long, but it's worth it and i've never not made it there and back in an hour. 
I like the tostada or tosdada salad (corn and flour tortilla respectively). The salad is bigger.
author: Elsa E.

description: Very dissapointed with my bowl because the al pastor tasted horrible. I expected better. I've had great experiences here, but my last one was depressing
author: Cesar F.

description:
Another late night at the office, another chance to try some restaurant close by.  Cringing at the thought of Fuzio or Chevy's at the nearby Embarcadero 1 or 2 or whatever, I sought something better.

Orale Orale offered me a little taste of freshness in the form of a beef and chicken enchilada with beans and rice on the side.  For $8.67 (including sales tax), I had a pretty enjoyable dinner in my hands in less than 10 minutes.

Good stuff ... and decent prices. They accept credit cards! Yeah!
author: Jamie W.

description:
Step 1. Don't eat anything on Friday morning.
Step 2. When you get hungry around 11am, start rustling up the posse.
Step 3. At 11:30 head for Orale Orale while they still have tables available and order the CRAB ENCHILADAS (Fridays only).
Step 4. Thank me later.

Beef taquitos are amazing. Chimichangas are amazing. There's really no way to go wrong at Orale Orale.
author: Ben R.

description:
Extra star since they are keeping the prices low in the FiDi.  A burrito supreme is around $6 and they are not tiny.  I got their Veggie Burrito Surpreme for $5.70.  That's a steal in the Fidi.  It was loaded with guac, sour cream, beans, lettuce, rice and cheese.  Also comes with a small container of salsa.  It hit the spot and I will def. be back even though I work like over 5 blocks away.  It's still worth it!

they also have a baby burrito going for $3.50 or so.  It's just rice, meat and beans though.  If you like that, you can get a baby burrito.  And I agree with other yelpers that they should throw in the chips for free.  

Def. will be back to try their other items.
author: AhLin C.

description:
OK, wait wait.  Stop and read it first before hammering with the sexual innuendos.    Yes, I thought the exact same thing as I walked in here.  

Now, usually the place is jam "cinco de mayo" packed.  i mean, out the heezy with starvin' marvins' dotting the street.  today, we leisurely strolled right in and sat down near the wall.  

the place isn't super clean nor super decorated.  think Mel's Diner from "Alice" meets high class roach coach.   coupled with the low ceilings, dirty walls, and no lights, i didn't even know what the buzz was all about.

but make no mistake, never judge a book by it's cover.  and the saying goes for, and ironically, a mexican joint.

i got the taco and enchilada combo; my buddy got the beef burrito.   the pork enchilada was lardy good with chunks of meat.   maybe 3 inches, it was covered in delicious stringy melted cheese.  the taco was one bad mother.  the hard shell was fried hard 'day of' with loads of carne asada topped with a garden of lettuce and layered with a sheet of guac.  aye ca rumba.   

the free chips and salsa aka 'molten lava' were good.    my lips were on fire and i was screaming 'agua por FAVOR' to anyone that would listen.  

overall, the food was actually good.  i wouldn't say authentic, but it would be right between taco hell and chevy's.  not exactly meat out of a metal squeeze tube and not exactly spit fire grilled meats.  but it is enough to get by, if you have the urge to fiesta on the peso.  

now for the minus two star piece.  the $.  ok, if i was a smart restaurateur i would of inquired more.  how a $8.75 combo muscled its way into a $16 lunch, i don't know.   but after further examination, the difference between a beef taco (offered) and a carne asada (ordered) taco is $2.  ah, then add the $2 CAN soda.  it wasnt even mexican coke (did you know they use cane sugar in mexico?)  tax and tip and you're pushing $16.  yeah not cool.  i feel as if the waiter probably knew but didn't offer to tell.  which is ok, it's not his job to relay what is already written on the menu.  so, be wary.  

man, if he charged me for one more thing, he'd be sleeping with the pescados.
author: Isaac L.

description:
Alright Ch'All

Orale Orale is the best Burrito Joint in the Fi-Ni.  

For all of you who are saying I spent my life eating the best burritos in the world in some little town in the middle of Jalisco...you are missing the point.

This is not the best burrito shop in the entire world - just the best burrito shop in the Downtown Area of SF and given the shittyness of the competition it shines like a Supahstar.

The Salsa is spicy and fresh, they cook with lard, the beans taste like something worth eating. The burritos are very good, the pork enchiladas are terrific...and who the hell cares what the rice tastes like? - it's rice dude.

Granted, the line is always out the door, so I spose if you want to stay away, that's OK with me.
author: E R.

description:
I came here for the Wednesday fish taco special and was really disappointed. The fish wasn't warm at all, it was rubbery and overly battered. And it was in tiny little strips. And the sauce tasted like thousand island dressing. And the flour tortilla was thick and bland. 

They only get one more star because I haven't had much else, but it really isn't worth the 15 min wait in line for a table. There are better fish tacos at the Ferry Building.
author: Katie D.

description:
At first I thought this place was  Mexican brothel, so you can imagine my disappointment when I realized what kind of tacos they were actually selling.  

I am spontaneous, though, and I replaced my disbelief with a plate of beans and beef, which was nearly as satisfying as some afternoon delight.  I still wanted to take a nap afterward, too.
author: Sam M.

description:
I went here for my lunchbreak this past week to catch up with an old high school friend and even though it was a late lunch the place was still packed.  Luckily, we only had a party of 2 and got a table relatively quick.

I ordered the seafood burrito and my friend ordered the chimichanga.  The food has always been on point when I've gone here and the salsa is very good and hot.  Service was extremely quick and we got our food so fast we thought we had to rush back to work and still had 20 minutes left so we sat around (place was emptying out by then) and caught up some more.

Food is good, service is quick.  No complaints.
author: Ruben P.

description:
This is my favorite place for one thing and one thing only - their red sauce enchiladas!  They have the most unique flavor - almost nutmeg-y - and they are addictive!  I cannot seem to order anything else, and when I do,  I miss my enchiladas!
The people are wonderful and friendly.  
The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is the long wait in line.  They need to expand their dining room (just try to go early).
I strongly recommend this place!!
author: Sonya M.

description: This was one of my favorite restaurants when I worked downtown. It's a family business, open for lunch and dinner. There is often a line out the door - one is for take-out, another is to sit-down, so be sure to get in the right line! They carry Mexican Coke with real sugar, and they have drink specials during happy hour. It may not be the best Mexican food that you've ever had, but you cannot beat the location, speed, and friendly staff. Over time, they came to recognize me and always greeted me warmly.
author: J K.

description:
If I could give this place 10 stars I would....it's that good. The salsa is amazing as other people have noted. I think we should start a campaign for the owners of Orale Orale to take over all other mexican restaurants in SF.

Best place for lunch downtown...PERIOD.

I recently moved back to San Francisco and am very excited to go to Orale Orale on a regular basis again. In 3 years away from the Bay Area I didn't taste better chicken enchiladas.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Allow me to deconstruct one of their signature dishes, the $6.50 Burrito Supremo, Pork meat version:

- 80% rice that looks pretty, but tastes like the mildly salty cheap filler material that it really is. I'm not kidding the big slimy burrito is 80% rice. Cost estimate 7 cents.
- 5% lean but tasteless pork. Three (3) medium sized chunks. Before ordering, I asked the earnest waiter what type of pork would be inside and he said "carnitas". HA! carnitas? He was a Mexican fellow, but one who seems to have never been to an actual taqueria -- or has been brainwashed by those villainous FiDi landlords. The pork was lean for sure, but tasted like it had been boiled in salt water with no other flavor! Cost estimate: 20 cents.
- 5% pinto beans that taste just okay. Cost estimate: 1 cent.
- 5% okay chewy flour tortilla. Cost estimate: 2 cents.
- 2% sour cream. Cost estimate: 3 cents.
- 2% guacamole, Cost estimate: 4 cents.
- 1% salsa. Cost estimate: 1 cent.

Hey, I'm MORE than willing to pay a fair or premium price for great ingredients excellently prepared, but $6.50 for 38 cents worth of material that tastes bland and uninspired!?

But it's actually worse. I'm pretty sure they recycle their chips and (probably) the salsa off the tables.  Just try turning your keyboard over and banging it lightly on your desk. What comes out? Mostly bits of short hairs, human skin, and whatever falls off of your fingers and out of your fingernails - just like when you paw into the basket of chips that gets passed on with all the "goodies" to the next customer. If anyone doubts me, go there several times at different times of day and watch closely the behavior of the chips and salsa servers.
author: David N.

description:
The men running this place are absolutely THE nicest folks I've ever had the pleasure of being served by at a restaurant. They're extremely attentive, take careful note of your order and project a truly friendly vibe.

Their burritos are gigantic and make for a reasonably priced lunch in the Financial District. A bottled soda (viva Jarritos!) and a hefty burrito ran just about $7 and change. I'm hard pressed to find any objections about this place, so I suppose my only complaint would have to be the lack of steaming or grilling of the burritos. Oh well.

I've always bemoaned the lack of good Mexican fare in the Financial District, so I wish I'd found this place sooner. Apparently my dad has known about Orale for a while and failed to mention it to me. Thanks a lot, old man.
author: Alex C.

description:
I walked in.. less than 10 bucks... 

Not bad.

Little did I know its more like a 2 for 1 deal...

The portions are STINKING HUGE. Lunch AND dinner for 1 price? I'll take it anyday.

Oh yea, the food's not bad either.

-1 star for the crazy crowds at noon time.
author: Stanley L.

description: I miss you Orale Orale.  THE best Mexican restaurant in the Financial District.  There's a reason why the line is long at this place.  It's good!  Chimichanga and the breakfast burrito are my favorite.  The plates come with rice/beans where are very good.  Hope to see you soon!
author: Jason N.

description:
I work right next door, so I was really hoping this place would be good.  But alas, it is not.  I've tried their burritos and chili rellenos - all generally flavorless.  Don't get me wrong - it doesn't taste bad, it just doesn't taste good either.  Just kind of watered down and mushy.  The only thing there that has spice and flavor is their chips and salsa if you dine in, but that is not enough to entice me to come back.  

Just because this place is not a chain doesn't mean it's good Mexican food.  This place definitely does not compare to the taquerias in the Mission.  I'll take Chipotle or Rubio's over Orale Orale any day, even though they are not "authentic."
author: Leslie L.

description:
Who are the people who love this place - did they have their tongues surgically removed?  Have they never eaten Mexican food anywhere except El Torito?  I get it - compared to El Torito - this place is the bomb.  

Bottom line, if you are looking for a good or great Mexican place in FiDi, you can forget it - doesn't exist.  If you are looking for the average overstuffed gut-bomb burrito with no seasoning on a cold and doughy tortilla with oh-so-crappy 3-day old salsa, then this is the place for you.
author: Michele O.

description:
Pretty decent!

I am a major Mexican food snob and turn up my nose at most places that other people swear are "authentic" or assume are good because they are in the Mission.  

This place is pretty decent stuff! I've had a sit down meal here once and the service was good.  Another time I got it to go and can't complain.
author: Lindsey H.

description: Had the beef burrito to go for my lunch break.  The inside wasn't evenly balanced and there wasn't a whole lot of beef and the fillers didn't make it taste any better than a chipotle.  It wasn't greasy but it also didn't have that "fresh" vibe you may get at a baja fresh or chipotle.  I'll have to try their fish tacos or something next time.
author: Kevin W.

description:
After reading a lot of really good reviews of this place on Yelp, I decided to give this place a try. I also notice that there's always a long line coming out of this place during lunch time so I had a pretty big breakfast and got there after 1pm and although there were a ton of people eating inside, there wasn't a line for take out.

I ordered the enchiladas combo.  They were OK and I really loved the salsa they gave me.  I do agree that the food is not bad but it's also not spectacular or really great....just OK.  They do give huge portions and it's pretty cheap considering all of the surrounding places that charge an arm and a leg for lunch.  

I'll have to try something else when I feel like going back.  The crab enchiladas on Fridays sounds awesome so I'll definitely be trying that out.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Faster-than-a-speeding-bullet service.  I ordered, sat in one of the 4 chairs next to the wall to wait, not thinking the dude behind me would want to squeeze in the corner chair, so I sat with my foot tucked behind me (yeah, 2nd grade style...I was in jeans).  Well, he sat right on it.  My foot, I mean.  No sooner could I get my foot loose from his caboose, when my "veggie supremo" was ready!

I HEAR some amazing things about the margs...not that I'd know...

UPDATE:
I have continued to patronize this joint with satisfaction.  However, on my latest visit, at a non-rush hour, here's how the exchange went:
me: May I please have a beans and rice burrito?
lady: Bean and rice only?
me: yes
lady: small burrito?
me: regular size
lady: bean and...?
me: beans and rice.  nothing else.  just beans and rice

Go find nice spot to sit, open aluminum foil, cut into burrito, find...
bean and cheese.
no rice.

?????
author: Ariana N.

description:
Ah, the Financial District - the Khaki Capital of San Francisco.  Alive with hustle, bustle and the warm crackle of a thousand handheld data devices.  Is there a more likely cradle for authentic Mexican food?

Yes.

So the good people at Orale Orale (roughly translated "Who's Your Daddy?") clearly had the right idea when they set up shop across the street from the Gap at Embarcadero Center.  

First, The Good:
1.  It isn't Baja Fresh, Taco Bell or Chevy's.  There's no "El Machino" churning out tortillas while overly-peppy waiters clap Happy Birthday to some poor bastard whose work friends clearly hate him.  In fact, there are no peppy waiters at Orale.  There are savvy business men who, if the Health Department allowed them, would pre-chew your food so that it would take you less time to eat it.
2.  You will never want for chips and salsa.  They're on the table when you sit down and they'll be refilled before the last one is gone.  This, my friends, is the essence of a good Mexican Restaurant.

Now, the Less Good:
1.  Remember what I said about non-peppy waiters?  Well, it's great when you're in a hurry, but not the best for casual diners who don't want to go back to the office.  They really don't want you to stay long, and that might be a problem if you've decided to play hooky and get tanked at lunch.
2.  The food doesn't stand a chance on "Top Chef," but -- wait, maybe this one belongs in the "good" section.  The food is tasty, but hardly award-winning.  Y'know? It is, however, superior - in every way - to the El Machino corporate style of any Baja Mess.

Oh, and did I mention it's reasonably priced?  Four stars, sir.  Four stars.
author: Richard T.

description:
Orale Orale is probably the best Mexican food in the FiDi!  Now don't get all excited now, because if you've tried the Mexican food in the FiDi, then you know it's nothing to pee yourself over.  

As with all Mexican restaurants in the FiDi, the burritos are very watery, and not the good kind of oily delicious watery, but the water watery, which really takes the taste out of the burrito.  I got the chicken supreme burrito, but I had so little meat that it might have well been a water and rice burrito. Maybe I should be nicer? It wasn't that bad...I'd still rather get these burritos than the ones at Palapas.  

Another unsettling factor was that the chips didn't come with the burrito (I paid $1 for chips) and the salsa is very, surprise, watery.  

I would probably come back here because if I want Mexican in the FiDi, I would have no other choice. Oh how great it would be if Le Cumbre was in the FiDi!
author: James C.

description:
Forget the burrito's people.  Get the enchilada's or the chimichanga, or the Taco Salad.  All extremely delicious.  Quick service, reasonable prices, endless chips and salsa.  Best Mexican downtown. 

I just discovered that they are open for dinner!  Great place to stop off after work if you need a quick fix!
author: Laura D.

description: I frequent this place probably a couple times a year and the food is consistently good.  one thing i did notice on my last visit was that the prices have gone  up and the portions have gone down, perhaps just a sign of the times, but to charge $2.50 for a can of coke? at least the chips and salsa are still fee.  Another thing to note is that this place  gets extremely busy during lunch time. Otherwise, its a good place to get decent mexican.
author: WJDL P.

description:
I ate here with my coworker. Never ever noticed this place.  We sit down and it looks pretty authentic. I liked the chips but the salsa made my mouth burn. The burrito that I ordered looked impressive but it was not all that great. I might try something different the next time I go back. 

Prices are reasonable.
author: Leena C.

description: Well prepared dishes.   Unlike some other Mexican restaurants I've been to, the food here is not super salty.  Very quick service and good prices.
author: Jay S.

description: This place used to be the spot!!  I used to go here a few years ago a lot, but lately, their food has gone downhill.  My go to meal was the chicken chimichanga cuz it was sooo good!  Recently I had one and it just tasted so damn bland.  I don't understand. I mean there is hella meat in it but that doesn't make up for flavor.  Also, the salsa isn't as spicy as it used to be. And what the heck is that smell??? Damn, it smells like shit on that street.  Too bad they can't close the door because the line is always out the door.  At least people still love it there.  I'll go somewhere else...
author: Michelle H.

description: Came here on a friday and ordered their crab enchilada. First of all.. it was expensive (and not just for my meal, but everything on the menu is overpriced for mexican food). Second of all, it was drenched in cheese, and not in the good 'ooh yummy cheese' way, but in the 'i'm going to have a heart attack and this is kind of disgusting' way. Oh and did I mention that the food was barely warm? Yeah, not a fan. Will not be coming back again.
author: Maria G.

description: love this place, a slice of the Mission in downtown SF
author: Margarita B.

description: This place the pretty good for those desparate for Mexican food in the Financial District (myself included!).
author: Lisa R.

description: Pretty good vegetarian burrito, and under $5!  The eat-in option is a little less than glamorous, lots of neon, fluorescent lighting and usually a Spanish language footbol game on the telly in the background.  The service is quick though and the bathroom is not as bad as you'd expect!  If you're stuck downtown after 5 and need to eat cheap and quick, it's definitely a top choice.
author: Molly B.

description: Alright, it's going up a star. They were nice enough to let me combine both chicken and beef into my flautas, which means that the were made fresh for me :)
author: Alita M.

description:
This place used to be a staple in my lunch diet when I worked in the city.  A must go before 11:30 otherwise expect to wait a long time for a table.  A Friday favorite was the crab enchiladas.

Just recently relocated back to the city and decided to go there for lunch.  First impression - they have not remodeled this place since I was last there over ten years ago.  Cracks are in the ceiling and floors.  Service was poor and one of the busboys smelled like he hadn't showered in weeks.  The enchiladas aren't even as good as they used to be, but then again, maybe the bad smell of the guy clearing the tables impaired my taste buds.

Only giving them a 2-star cuz this used to be a fave of mine.  Couldn't bear to give them anything less.

Definitely not going back
author: Sharon S.

description:
This mainstay in the FiDi has gone down hill.  I've eaten here for 10+ years and one of my favorite dishes is the seafood burrito.  Twice now, I've gotten the dish cold and with key ingredients missing.  I am not sure if there have been changes in the kitchen but it is showing.

The staff is still good and efficient and the salsa nice and hot...but until they get their kitchen back in line -- two poor experiences is enough.
author: Laurence H.

description:
The burrito does not hold itself. When i bring it back to work to eat, its a gooey sloshy mess. A burrito should be able to stand on its own. 

It is cheap though. i'll give them that. I think Pancho Villa is about one star better than this one.
author: Sarav C.

description:
Mexican food at work usually means Chevy's, but this place definitely made me drop that fake wannabe Tex Mex stuff. You're talking serious Mexican when you can't really pronounce over half the items on the menu. 

Along with the usual beef, pork, chicken -adas and -os, they offer unique dishes like seafood burrito and a jumbo schrimp plate in cream sauce, both highly recommended.

This is a great place for fast, cheaper and delicious food in the financial district.
author: Ed L.

description:
Really good Mexican food located in the financial district/embarcadero area.   This is as authentic as you can get around here and they're pretty good.

The main thing they can change immediately are their chips and salsa!  Their chips are stale and taste straight out of some old bag.  Hitting a mexican spot to eat includes their chips and theirs suck unfortunately.  But the food, I'd give them an A- .
author: Marie H.

description:
I used to live a few blocks from this restaurant and all I have to say is CEVICHE TOSTADAS. They are amazing here. 

It's more of a lunch place since it is in the Financial District--as in, you better get here before 11:30 or after 1:00 if you don't want to wait in line.

I usually go here for dinner since they open until 8:00pm. It's less crowded. Steer clear of the fish tacos.
author: Cindy P.

description:
Orale, Orale is right by my gym and I can't tell you how  hard it is to come and go the gym everyday at lunch time or after work and have to walk down the street and smell the delicious smell of carne asada grilling as it wafts through the air. 

I went in for the first time last night to have dinner with my bff, who works across the street  and swears by it, and we had  a good meal. I was a little disappointed that my chicken crispy tacos were made with shredded chicken and red sauce (I'd assumed they'd be made with grilled chicken like crispy tacos usually are). But, all in all, the food was good. The lettuce was finely shredded, there was  a generous portion of rice and refried beans, the chips and salsa were promptly re-filled without our asking and our servers were great.  Next time, I'll order the chile relleno--I stole a bite of my bff's and it was soooo good.
author: Dee I.

description:
It's kind of too bad for Orale that Pancho Villa opened up nearby, because until recently Orale laid claim to the best burrito in the Financial District.  Still, it's pretty solid food, and they use some kind of saffron rice in their burritos, which is pretty compelling.  It's one of the few places you can get a chimichanga, too, and those are always little fried bits of goodness (actually at Orale they're pretty big fried bits of goodness).

Service is quick and efficient (despite the daily long lines) and prices are good.
author: Marco C.

description:
Quick, pretty tasty and (as Jewel tells ya) margaritas to go!  One of the most reasonably priced restaurants in the area, Orale Orale's staff is friendly and prompt and the food is consistent. 

Hi-lights for me are the flautas, salsa (spicy!), great snow crab enchiladas (Fridays only!).  Also, I know that no matter how long the line is, I'm going to make it back to work in under an hour- these guys haul a**.

I'll say I'm not a fan of the chips- not warm, rather burnt on occasion and really, really not salty enough. Still, worth a shot
author: Jenni D.

description:
I've been working around the corner from this place about a year and never had it till today. As i was pondering what to have for lunch and going through my usual choices (burger, sandwich, Chinese and gyros) i started to think of Mexican food.

hit this place around 2 pm and no line what so ever. I ordered a chicken burrito supremo which costs only $4.99. The meat was juicy and they were generous with it. good amount of rice, beans, onion, sour cream and guacamole.  My only grip was that they didn't give me any chips and the burrito was wrapped kind of loosely. For a Mexican place in the FiDi it is not bad. I was very satisfied for lunch and will add it to my lunch options in the future.
author: Alfredo N.

description:
Solid breakfast burritos.  Really solid.  The kind that could cure hangovers and maybe even promote world peace (or at least office peace, 'cuz you no longer have a raging headache).  

No lines, no waiting around 9 am.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Mexican restaurants are a dime a dozen anywhere in California.  You know?  But you know someplace is special when there is a line coming out the door...  During Lunch!

Yes, the food is good and hearty... But you may have to wait a few minutes during lunch, especially if you want to get a table.  Take-out is a bit faster..   And better still, call in your order ahead of time!

Yes, good food, good location and good pricing!
author: R G.

description: This is, hands-down, my favorite restaurant in the city. It covers all the bases - convenient to get to from my office, fast table turnover, fantastic food, great margaritas, and most importantly, head man Alex is the coolest dude in town. All the dishes are tasty and the waiters are always willing to give solid recommendations, and did I mention the margaritas? Yeah, emails are so much more easy to deal with after a lunchtime visit to Orale Orale. Go there now.
author: Drew S.

description:
Orale is the best Mexican food I've found in the financial district. It's perfect for a quick lunch, however even better if you can dine in. The chips and salsa are great, however the margaritas are unbelievable. Have it on the rocks. The problem? You can never stay for just one...

The staff are incredibly friendly. 

Orale fills up around lunch time, well worth the wait!
author: Natalie C.

description:
The ying and yang of Mexican food on the doorstep of my office.  I had a meal in the evening here of a beef enchilada and a taco and it was delicious, the carne asada was not even remotely chewy and the rice was wonderful, by far the best taqueria rice I've had in Northern California.  The sauce on the enchilada was superb and it all came in a handy round foil container that I could munch away at my desk while I toiled into the evening.  The refried beans were out of a tin and generic and bland and the cheese that topped everything was pretty tasteless.

Impressed with this experience however I went for lunch and tried to order a regular burrito.  I don't care for the "super" burrito with the frankly un-necessary addition of sour cream, guacamole and cheese and like mine really simply done.  They had trouble with this concept when I ordered my burrito minus those embellishments and I had three seperate people check that I really didn't want another 700 calories of gloop added to the burrito and then wanted to make sure that I wanted each of the other ingredients.  I asked for refried beans in my burrito and when I got back to the office they had put sour cream and black beans in and omitted the salsa.  Not good.
author: Tony S.

description:
mmMMmm... I just had their Huevos con Chorizo... and it was yummy! the refried beans were tasty with lots of cheese on it, the eggs were a tad overcooked (my personal taste) but it was still yummy. It also helps that I was able to phone in my order 10 mins before they stopped serving breakfast and walk around the corner from work to pick it up! Tortillas were nice and hot, and salsa was hot as well. 
I've had their burritos for lunch and it'okay. Had a tostada once, hated it. So I'd stick to breakfast, and in this area, $6.50 is a deal.
author: Mina T.

description:
Wow...can't believe I haven't tried this place earlier!!!
I can see how this is a hit or miss. I do not eat spicy food so that tells you I like Americanized Mexican food. 
$9 for a combo of enchilada/Taco and that comes with beans/rice.
It came with real chunks of chicken and ground beef. No oil dripping from my taco. Big plus.
Table service available & seperate cashier if you are ordering to-go.
The only cons I can think of is the price on their drinks. $2 for a can of soda :(
author: Maggie C.

description:
Seafood burrito yum very tasty and huge.  Also killer chips and salsa.  Salsa is resh and muy spicy.
Long wait so, like others said, get there early or just resign yourself to a wait.  It's worth it, and your alternative is to schlep to the Mission so no whining.
You will be full, and satisfied.  You will doze at your desk all afternoon, and you will have money left over.
author: Mike K.

description:
what happened to this place? i used to frequent this place a couple of years ago and the burritos used to be decent. came here last night and really regretted it. grilled chicken burrito tasted bland and it fell apart as the tortilla was thin. the chips were stale and dry. taco bell's quesadillas taste better.

next time, i'll just go look for a taco truck or head down to the mission for better mexican food.
author: ally o.

description:
Some coworkers and I were looking for a place to eat in the financial district when we came across this restaurant. 

The service there was pretty good and we got our food pretty quickly. I ordered a Carne Asada Burrito Supremo and I was not impressed at all. It was bland and boring. I guess I'm just used to real Mexican food that's all.

One good thing from going there is that we saw that blackbird that is attacking everyone on Front Street on our way back!
author: Tony C.

description: Cheap, fast, and edible. I think they use Rice-a-Roni instead of normal rice, though.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I dig this place. It's a taco shop that tries to act like a mexican restaurant, and I get charged a dollar or two more than I really feel like I should, but I'm always very satisfied with the food. Big, big burritos. They don't hold back on the cheese (although too few items come with cheese). And, most importantly, the carne asada is flavorful. I lived in San Diego for five years, and the mexican food up here (yes, even at the most highly-recommended taco shops in the mission) just strikes me as bland. The carne asada at Orale is the closest I've found to SD quality.

So yeah, beyond the Financial District prices and minor identity crisis, this is a solid taco shop that's well, well worth a visit if you happen to be in the area. Oh, and the waiters range from friendly to super-friendly in my experience, which is always a plus (if I'm not mistaken, their take-out menu is cheaper than their sit-in menu, though, so you may benefit in missing out on that aspect).
author: Wayne W.

description:
I'll wait as long as i gotta for an order of huevos rancheros.  And if you DONT love this place, its cause you "ain't odered they hoovoes rancheros yet!"  MMMMMM Mmmmm!  

Love,
Sara
author: Sara W.

description:
Very good enchiladas and expectedly very busy at lunchtime.

I thought the chips weren't great, but the salsa was spicy and perfect.
author: G J J.

description:
DELICIOSO!  I was always intimidated by Orale Orale and it's line-out-the-door.  One day a friend of mine said we should meet there for lunch at 11:30 on Friday--crab enchillada day.  The crab enchilladas are topped with a white sauce, and the plate includes refried beans and rice.  I think about crab enchilladas all week long now, and I get upset if I can't make it to Orale Orale on Friday.  I tried to order something new when I was there yesterday, but I couldn't bare the thought of being disappointed and having to wait yet another week for my crab enchilladas.  Now that I have read some of the reviews, I will definitely try to order some enchilladas with red sauce next time.  

And yes, the service if fast and friendly.  It has to be to keep up with the crowds.  You will feel pressure to order the moment you sit down and you will feel pressure to leave the moment you finish eating, but folks in the FiDi appreciate that kind of thing.  We can't all have the luxury of having a whole hour for lunch.  Sometimes it's all about inhaling your food and running back to the office, while appreciating the fact that you have had something to eat that is not a sandwich and did not come from a food court.
author: Kandi K.

description:
I tried the carne asada and chicken tacos with a friend at lunch one day, and I was enamored with the chicken, less so with the carne.

I gave this restaurant five stars because I love spice--if any food gets me sweaty, it gets me reeling. I have masochistic tendencies which push my tastes toward transcendence through mouth-fire. And their salsa is among the spiciest I've tasted, seeing as how I ate enough of it to leave a significant amount of my taste buds nearly useless after lunch.

The chips and salsa kept on coming, and for the price it was quite nice, especially considering some of the prices in the FiDi at lunchtime. Repeat visits are a guarantee.

Edit from a later visit: The pork burrito smothered in chile verde sauce was one of the more tasteless ventures into Mexican cuisine I've experienced. Did the salsa burn off my taste buds beforehand? I don't think so.
author: Andrew S.

description:
The 4/5 stars people must definitely think the 3 stars mean Taco Bell.  And they mustn't have tried the Pancho Villa on 16th and Mission (not the one on the Wharf, that's another disaster).  Because of the ranks and hoorays from friends about this place, i decided to give it a try on the sunny Friday lunch time.

One word: Tasteless!

My wife had the seafood supremo burrito, well it suppose to be a "store special" with a special sign next to it.  It came in an aluminum foil box and all, and I thought, "wow, this should be good".  Opened it up with knife and fork, oh my God!  What is this?  The thing was like a swimming pool wrapped with a piece of COLD tortilla.  Slimy, watery, tasteless!  And I am sorry, where is the seafood?  Upon closer inspection, there are "dog food sized" bits of gamy fish, and shrimp?  Well, I found 1 (solo, uno) piece of quarter of shrimp which well, was also tasteless and hard.  Maybe I have set my expectation too high.  Comparing this piece of shit to Pancho Villa's steak and shrimp burrito?  This is dog food!

I had the crab enchilada, which was a special only available on Friday.  After taking off the cover, I thought, "wow, where's the food?"  Tasteless trace of crab (crap) wrapped between two layers of tortillas and covered with a ton of melted cheese... and served with tasteless rice and refried beans.  Looks like puke from a shindig.  

Total:  $18.  I should have just moved a couple stores over and get the subway for $2.99 or taco bell Nacho Grande for $3.49 with a drink.

Totally OVERRATED!
author: Gary T.

description:
I love this place more than a stripper loves a pole (which I'm beginning to think is not that much and that they're more into the money than actual love for the pole, and I'm beginning to think that even though they look like they love that pole (and I mean REALLY LOVE that pole with everything they do with it) they're just pretending, which is just heartbreaking and a prime illustration of how capitalism has degraded our social values). 

Regardless, this place did not put me in one of my "weeping softly for humanity" moods. Quite the opposite, it gave me hope that human race can come together and put aside who owns what territory, who's Gods are right, and who's weapons are better and just sit down to have spicy salsa and chips at Orale Orale. Then after a hearty meal with good service, they'll come to a revelation of the pointlessness of all their hatred when such Mexican restaurants existed. A new society will arise with the pursuit of knowledge and science, and mankind will be in a second golden age of enlightenment. We will have found cures to almost all diseases, harnessed the power of free energy, ridded the world of pollution, and close to unlocking the secrets and mysteries of the universe. Peace will blanket the world in harmony. All thanks to spicy salsa and a generous serving of tostada salad. We will hold the salsa and tostada salad in such high regard that we will build a temple for it, lavishing it with gifts and offerings. Then rival temples of the burrito and taco will arise claiming that theirs is the true divine. We will ignore these cults at first but then their followings will grow larger and larger. Families will be divided, friends will become enemies. Debates will turn to arguments which turn into fights which turns to conflicts and finally all out WAR!!! Mankind will be devastated from the fighting because with all our science we built space-guns and laser-bombs, WHY?!? WHY DID WE BUILD SPACE-GUNS AND LASER-BOMBS? From the ashes, we will rebuild and question how we fell, some will say it was human nature, some will say it was God punishing us for worshipping a false idol. Me? I say it was because THEY DIDN'T BUILD ENOUGH FUCKING TAQARIAS LIKE ORALE ORALE!!

I came here for lunch and although there was a line to be seated it moved quite quickly (for those of you who have never been and just want something to go, just go straight to the register, don't worry only a few people will stare at you with hatefully eyes because they think you're cutting, but all there anger will melt away like the cheese on my tostada salad). The service was prompt, refilling the chip bowl and salsa even when it showed a slight sign of being depleted. The serving was very large, so for the financial district, it was like a Godzilla meal crushing all other meals and their homes as the other food ran away in fear. It's actually quite devastating for those meals without food house property insurance. 

This combined with a the food being good with a not so monstrous price of 8 bucks boosts this place to 5 star territory. The only way this place could be better is if they offered an assortment of salsas.....and helped me conquer the Balkan Peninsula.
author: Youchen W.

description: I had a shredded beef burrito from Orale Orale today. It was quite mediocre but edible. If all you want is something to stuff your face quickly with and happen to be in the area then it is acceptable.
author: Christopher K.

description: Waiter had about ten tables.  However my food from the kitchen was fast and decent.  However i was never told the to prices on the to go menu--which the register lady clearly saw me pick up--was different from the dining in price.  Also the salsa was wayyyyy to hot and chips on the side of toooo cruchy.  3.5
author: Nathan K.

description: The salsa is indescribably tasty. I think I could eat a whole bowl of it!
author: Rose K.

description:
Stop calling it or-ALL-ee. It's OR-uh-lay!

Pretty greasy, even for mexican, so lots of people don't like it. In my opinion, only the steak is okay. I keep away from the chicken (which is usually my preferred burrito or taco ingredient) cuz I think it's pretty gross.

And if you take out, they're fast.
author: Noah R.

description:
I have one word for you.

Breakfast. 

You have to try their breakfast burritos or their breakfast "plates" and make sure you try their salsa when you do. So YUMMY!

My coworker bought me birthday breakfast from this place and it seriously made my day.
author: Zoeboe D.

description: Not that impressed. Had a chile colorado burrito, and that's pretty much all that was in the burrito, though it had a side of r'n'b. The chunks of beef were a bit tough and large. Hmmm... that sounds a tad naughty. Orally! Orally!
author: Maximillian M.

description: I am a regular.....delicious salsa....great service....and good food.  Service staff is quiet - they take your order and get to work and dont stick around to chat.  Food comes fast and is very good.  My favorite thing about this place is the salsa.  Its hotter than most places, and the chips are great with it.  i only wish they would stay open later!
author: Matt W.

description: Went here for lunch and had the fish tacos. Not bad, though my standard has been set by Rubio's in San Diego, and this doesn't quite compare. Was really busy for lunch but only had to wait 5-10 minutes for a seat. Excellent salsa, though the rice and beans left something to be desired.
author: Matt W.

description: While not the best in town they are my favorite in the Financial District.  The "baby" burritos are a good option if you are counting calories.
author: David H.

description: I ordered a carne asada burrito here and immediately regretted it. The burrito itself was as soggy as a leftover bowl of cereal, then I took a bite. The meat and beans were runny, there was no zest or flavor to any of it, and the rice was stale and hard. I've returned since, but never to order, only to hang out with coworkers. Every time I see what they order, it's the same, soggy mess of beans and fried cheese. Pass on this place, your taste buds and arteries will thank you.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Orale Orale is a decent little Mexican restaurant with good food at good prices.

It certainly isn't the best Mexican food around, but its cheap and its a decent spot if you are looking for somewhere to get some food. The enchiladas are good, if even a bit greasy (even for Mexican).

The chips are not very good (I think they are just generic bagged chips from costco) but the salsa is definitely the best part of the experience. Really spicy and good.
author: Barron E.

description:
A decent place for some mexican food.

I admit when I have the early lunch option I tend to run over to this place because if I go later there is either a line or alot of people already at tables eating. I remember going here to dine there at 11:15 and by 11:45 people were already drooling and waiting for a table.


I admit,after a night of drinking I do think of this place....


I reccommend this place for people,but come around 11ish or after 1pm.
author: Mattee M.

description:
Get here early or pay the consequences.  Ok, I am being a little dramatic, but are you going to let a little line stop you from getting good Mexican food?

It's very busy during the lunch hour and we waited in line, which moves very quickly.  Sat down and snacked on the complimentary chips and spicy salsa, really good salsa might I add.  I ordered a chimichanga for $8.50 and my buddy ordered two enchiladas.  The chimichanga came with rice and cheese covered beans and was delicious.  The whole process took 1 hour.

**Hint** Avoid the line by arriving at 11:30am or sooner.

Service Friendly
Service Prompt
Food Good
Go Again
author: Po L.

description: Good service with a friendly waiter for the table service, but my food was pretty basic and not very tasty. I had the crab enchiladas which is a house specialty served only on Fridays. I figured since it was a special dish that I've never seen offered anywhere else, I'd try it. I was not impressed. I got a piece of shell in the filling which did not help, but really, the flavor was the bigger problem. It was more fishy-tasting than I was expecting, with the consistency of finely mixed tuna fish, and served in some kind of tomato-y sauce/seasoning which didn't compliment it well. I found myself enjoying the side of beans and rice more than the enchilada. The complimentary chips were bland. Beer wasn't served cold enough either - The chilled glasses were a nice touch, but the beer got to that almost-at-room-temperature range rather quickly, and I was not lingering over it. Boo! The salsa was spicy hot which was the best thing I ate there. My boyfriend liked his entree, so I MAY try again with a different item, but I'm in no rush.
author: Barbara K.

description:
This place makes me ill. 

No, really. I got sick here. The food is gross, not at all authentic and totally bland. And then the stomach cramps arrived...

Not pleasant. 

Also, the staff is super rude and would not engage me when I asked for a substitution. Huh? My take on the service is that they are lazy. That, and they simply don't care about making their customers happy.

All this place has going for it is that it is "Mexican" in the financial district, which is hard to find. But, take my advice, and wait for the real thing. This scum-hole is most definitely not it.
author: jasmine a.

description: I met some friends here for lunch yesterday and realized that I had been here once before.  There was a huge line out the door of all the people that wanted to eat their food.
